sen.j: 勧学院（かんがくいん）は平安時代の藤原氏の大学別曹である。
sen.e: Kangakuin was the Fujiwara clan's Daigakubesso (private academic facility) in the Heian period.
Kangakuin was the Fujiwara clan's Daigakubesso (private academic facility) in the Heian Period.
Kangakuin was the Fujiwara clan's Daigaku-besso (academic facility for nobles) in the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 大学寮の南側（左京3条1坊5町）の地にあったため、大学南曹（だいがくなんそう）とも呼ばれていた。
sen.e: Since it was located on the south side of Daigakuryo (Sakyo Sanjo Ichibo Gocho), it was also called Daigakunanso.
Since it was located on the south side of Daigakuryo (Sakyo Sanjo Ichibo Gocho), it was also called Daigakunanso.

Since it was located on the south side of Daigaku-ryo (the government facility to educate students who would later become bureaucrats) (the old address was go-cho, ichi-bo, Sakyo (west area of capital Kyoto)), it was also called Daigaku Nanso (facilities of Daigaku-ryo in the south).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 勧学院は弘仁12年（821年）、藤原冬嗣によって創建され、貞観14年（872年）以前に大学別曹として公認された。
sen.e: Kangakuin was established by the Fujiwara no Fuyutsugu in 821, and officially approved in or earlier than 872.
Kangakuin was established by the Fujiwara no Fuyutsugu in 821, and officially approved in or prior to 872.
Kangakuin was established by the Fujiwara no Fuyutsugu in 821, and officially approved in or prior to 872.

sen.j: 大学別曹は有力氏族の学生のためにつくられた寄宿舎である。
sen.e: Daigakubesso were dormitories for students from powerful clans.
Daigakubesso were dormitories for students from powerful clans.
Daigaku-besso were dormitories for students from powerful clans.

sen.j: 本来は大学寮内に寄宿しなければならないが､大学別曹として公認されると寮内に寄宿する学生と同等の資格で授業・試験に出ることが出来た。
sen.e: Although students of Daigakuryo had to live in Daigakuryo as a general rule, once a dormitory is approved as a Daigakubesso, students who lived in it became as qualified as those who lived in Daigakuryo to sit for classes and examinations of Daigakuryo.

Although students at Daigakuryo had to live within Daigakuryo as a general rule, once a dormitory was approved as a Daigakubesso, students living in it became as qualified as those who lived in Daigakuryo to sit for the classes and examinations of Daigakuryo.

Although students at Daigaku-ryo had to live within Daigaku-ryo as a general rule, once a dormitory was approved as a Daigaku-besso, students living in it became as qualified as those who lived in Daigaku-ryo to sit for the classes and examinations of Daigaku-ryo.

sen.j: のちには任官試験を経ずに地方官に任命される特権（年挙）を朝廷から認められた。
sen.e: Later, their students were given a special privilege (called 'Nenkyo') by the Imperial court to be appointed as a rural bureaucratic post without sitting for the appointment examinations.

sen.j: また、優秀者には学問料が払われて後の文章生への登用に有利に働いた。
sen.e: An aid money to study was provided for deserving students who took advantage of it to be appointed as a Monjo no Sho (a rank of advanced student) which was later instituted.

sen.j: また、藤原氏の公卿に慶事があると職員・学生達が挙って祝辞を述べに参上し、その答礼として彼らを饗宴でもてなすという「勧学院歩（かんがくいんのあゆみ）」という恒例行事があった。
sen.e: On celebratory occasions of court nobles of the Fujiwara clan, there were customary events called 'Kangakuin no ayumi' in which all the officials and students visited them to offer their congratulations and the court nobles gave banquets as a return.

sen.j: 維持管理は藤氏長者の職務とされ、藤原氏一門の大納言級から任じられる公卿別当、弁官から任じられる弁別当以下の職員の任免を行った。
sen.e: Kangakuin was operated by Toshi Choja (the chief of the Fujiwara clan) who conducted the appointment and dismissal of its posts: Kugyo Betto (the head principal) to which one of Dainagon (the Great Councilor) of the Fujiwara clan was appointed; Ben no Betto (a second principal) to which members of Benkan (the Board of Controllers) were appointed; and other officials.

sen.j: 財政は一族からの荘園寄付によって賄われており他の大学別曹に比べ､非常に豊かであった。
sen.e: It was extremely rich compared to other Daigakubesso, because it was financially supported by the donations from Shoen (manors) owned by the Fujiwara clan.

sen.j: 貴族社会の衰微とともに鎌倉時代には消滅したと言われているが、興福寺などの有力寺院が寺内に設けた僧侶育成機関に「勧学院」の名が用いられたのは、ここに由来していると言われている。
sen.e: It is said to have disappeared along with the demise of the aristocratic society, except for its name 'Kangakuin' which is said to have become the name of educational facilities of monks set up inside major temples such as Kofuku-ji Temple.
